data.title: How many Fed rate cuts in 2026?

data.data:
[EVIDENCE]: 1. [2026-02-20] 10-day weather forecasts for Minas Gerais show daily chances of rain and thunderstorms (AccuWeather / Meteoblue). 2. [2026-02-06] Somar Meteorologia reported Minas Gerais received 72.6 mm of rain (113% of historical average) for the week ending Feb 6. 3. The 2026/27 crop is currently in the bean-filling and maturation stages, not flowering, and rains are characterized as beneficial. 4. [2026-02-05] Conab projects a record 66.2 million bags for 2026 (+17.1% YoY). 5. [2026-02-18] Coffee futures hit a 7.25-month low due to improving crop prospects.
[ANALYSIS]: The recent and forecasted rainfall in Minas Gerais is highly beneficial for the 2026 Arabica crop, which is currently in the bean-filling and maturation stages rather than flowering. Data from Somar Meteorologia indicates precipitation is at 113% of the historical average, providing critical soil moisture for fruit development. While the previous analysis contained a slight hasty generalization by claiming supply-side risks were 'effectively eliminated'—as excessive rain closer to the harvest could still pose quality or logistical risks—the current weather undeniably supports Conab's record harvest projection of 66.2 million bags. This robust supply outlook is the primary driver pushing coffee futures to multi-month lows, heavily weighing on prices and justifying a bearish market sentiment.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: • (Trading Economics, 2026-02-20) USD/BRL at 5.2110, strongest BRL since May 2024.
• (Safras & Mercado / Anec, 2026-02-10) New soybean crop sales at 33.9%, ~10pp below historical average; attributed to strong BRL.
• (Reuters, 2026-01-28) Copom held Selic at 15% and signaled a possible cut in March.
• (CoinCodex, 2026-02-20) Very short-term model forecast: USD/BRL 5.23 in 24h (+0.14%).
• (CZ App, 2026-02-13) Mato Grosso 2025/26 production costs BRL 7,675.90/ha (+8% YoY).
[ANALYSIS]: CRITIQUE OF PRIOR ANALYSIS
1) Logical fallacies / reasoning risks
- Possible overgeneralization / weak analogy: Using soybean selling behavior as direct evidence for coffee selling behavior. It supports the *mechanism* (strong BRL can discourage selling of USD-priced exports), but it is not coffee-specific proof.
- Potential confirmation bias: The write-up weighted the “strong BRL discourages selling” narrative more heavily than countervailing drivers (e.g., producer liquidity needs, price level of coffee, basis/forward curves, weather) that were not in the evidence packet. The conclusion may be directionally right, but it’s narrowly supported.
- Mild recency bias: Anchoring on the latest USD/BRL print (5.2110) as “trend” without showing a time series. “Strongest since May 2024” indicates a notable level, but not necessarily an ongoing strengthening trend versus recent weeks.
- False precision: “Supportive for USD Arabica prices” is plausible but not demonstrated with any coffee flow/export/positioning data here. The chain is: stronger BRL → less selling → less hedge pressure → supportive USD coffee; each link is not evidenced in this packet.

2) Source specificity vs vagueness
- Strength: It cited specific outlets and dates for the USD/BRL level (Trading Economics), Copom signal (Reuters), farmer selling rate (Safras & Mercado / Anec), and costs (CZ App).
- Weakness: It did not cite any coffee-specific sources (e.g., Cecafe exports, ICE certified stocks changes, Brazil coffee farmer sales pace, export differentials). It also leaned on CoinCodex, which is not a fundamental macro/FX source and has limited evidentiary weight.

3) Sentiment tag justification
- “BULLISH” for Arabica is only weak-to-moderately justified from the provided evidence. The evidence strongly supports: BRL is strong and can discourage selling. But translating that into a bullish call on Arabica requires additional coffee-specific confirmation (export pace, producer hedge flow, differentials, stocks, weather). With only FX + an analogy from soybeans, a more defensible tag would be NEUTRAL (or at most mildly bullish with explicit caveats).

REVISED (IMPROVED) ANALYSIS
- Facts supported by the packet: BRL is at a relatively strong level (USD/BRL 5.2110; strongest since May 2024). In another Brazilian export crop (soybeans), commercialization is running below average and is explicitly attributed to the strong BRL (33.9% sold, ~10pp below average). Monetary policy is still restrictive (Selic 15%), but guidance suggests a potential March cut—i.e., a plausible future shift that could weaken BRL, though no weakening is yet evidenced beyond a tiny 24h model move (to 5.23).
- What can be concluded with high discipline: The current FX level/condition (strong BRL) is more consistent with *discouraging* Brazilian producer selling of USD-denominated commodities than encouraging it. That conclusion is directly supported by the soybean commercialization datapoint as evidence of the mechanism in practice, but it remains an inference for coffee.
- Coffee/Arabica implication (properly caveated): If coffee producers behave similarly to soybean producers when BRL is strong, then near-term producer selling/hedging pressure could be reduced, which would be mildly supportive for USD Arabica prices at the margin. However, the packet does not provide coffee-specific sales/export/hedging data; therefore, the appropriate stance is cautious and should be framed as a conditional, not a firm directional price call.
- Key watchpoint: Copom’s signaled March easing could become a catalyst for BRL softening; if BRL weakens meaningfully, the incentive to sell/hedge coffee typically rises, which could become a bearish offset for USD Arabica.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: NEUTRAL]

[EVIDENCE]: 1) [2026-02-09] Standard transit times Shanghai→Rotterdam via the Cape of Good Hope are now 40–45 days due to sustained Red Sea diversions. (IndustryIDX)
2) [2026-02-18] Red Sea shipping disruptions (and Panama Canal constraints) are described as long-term structural realities requiring network redesign. (Global Trade Magazine)
3) [2026-02-05] Major carriers have begun a gradual return to Suez Canal services, contributing to softening 2026 container contract rates. (Global Maritime Hub)
4) [2026-02-12] Port of Santos 7-day average vessel waiting time is ~2 days; Brazil Terminal waits reached up to 38 hours. (Kuehne+Nagel)
5) [2026-02-19] Port of Santos handled 12.7 million tonnes in Jan 2026 (+9.5% y/y), its best start to a year on record. (DatamarNews)
[ANALYSIS]: Critique of prior analysis:
- Potential logical issues:
  - Overgeneralization / weak linkage: The Red Sea/Suez evidence is about Asia→North Europe container lanes, but Brazilian Arabica exports to Europe often move on South America→Europe routes that may not be directly exposed to the same diversion dynamics. Using Shanghai→Rotterdam as a proxy for Brazil→Europe coffee flow risk risks a false causation / weak relevance error unless the specific lane mix (origins, transshipment points, carrier networks) is established.
  - Confirmation/recency bias: The conclusion leaned bullish on “tightening risk” primarily from recent disruption headlines and port statistics without quantifying whether delays are unusual vs baseline seasonal congestion at Santos.
  - Magnitude ambiguity: A ~2-day average vessel wait and up-to-38-hour terminal waits indicate friction but may be operationally normal at a high-throughput hub; the earlier write-up implied meaningful tightening without benchmarking.
- Source specificity:
  - Strength: It did cite concrete, dated data points and named sources.
  - Weakness: It made some claims that were not directly evidenced in the provided items (e.g., “higher landed costs” and “rollovers” were plausible but not demonstrated; “containerized coffee flows on affected routes” was asserted without lane-level confirmation).
- Sentiment tag justification:
  - “Bullish” was not fully justified from the evidence alone. The evidence supports “logistics noise/risk” more than a clear, sustained reduction in effective supply. Also, the noted gradual return to Suez and softening contract rates is a countervailing (potentially easing) factor.

Revised analysis (improved):
The evidence indicates elevated global ocean-network uncertainty and some congestion risk at Brazil’s primary export gateway, but it is insufficient to conclude a strong, directional tightening of Arabica supply.

- Global shipping reliability: Red Sea diversions materially extend Asia→North Europe transit times (40–45 days via Cape), and commentary frames Red Sea/Panama constraints as structural. However, these data points are lane-specific and do not, on their own, prove equivalent disruption for Brazil→consumer market coffee routes. They do suggest broader schedule unreliability and network knock-on effects (equipment positioning, service rotations), but the magnitude of impact on Brazilian coffee exports is not quantified here.

- Brazil export gateway (Santos): Record January throughput (+9.5% y/y) combined with ~2-day average vessel waiting and terminal waits up to 38 hours points to congestion/queuing potential. This supports a risk of shipment timing variability (delays/roll risk) rather than a confirmed, persistent bottleneck. Without historical comparison, it’s unclear whether conditions are meaningfully worse than typical peak-season operations.

Implication for Arabica prices: The evidence supports a moderate logistics-risk premium (timing uncertainty) rather than a definitive supply shock. Countervailing evidence (gradual Suez return and softening contract rates) implies some easing in ocean freight conditions, tempering bullish implications.

Net: logistics conditions are a mild supportive factor on risk, but overall signal from the provided evidence is best characterized as neutral-to-slightly-bullish rather than clearly bullish.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: NEUTRAL]

[EVIDENCE]: - Brazil exported 2.78 million 60-kg bags of coffee in January 2026, a 30.8% YoY decrease (Cecafé / MercoPress, 2026-02-10).
- Revenues totaled $1.175 billion, down 11.7% YoY, implying ~28% higher average export prices (Cecafé, 2026-02-10; calculated as revenue ratio 0.883 / volume ratio 0.692).
- Port of Santos handles ~80% of Brazil's coffee exports, with 55% of vessels facing delays or changes and delay index at 73% (RAW RESEARCH FINDINGS).
- Drewry World Container Index fell 1% to $1,919/40ft amid softening demand and 31 blank sailings (Drewry / RAW RESEARCH, 2026-02-20).
[ANALYSIS]: January 2026 Brazilian coffee exports dropped 30.8% YoY to 2.78M bags due to tighter Arabica supplies, but revenues fell only 11.7% to $1.175B, reflecting ~28% higher average prices. Localized bottlenecks at Port of Santos (80% of exports; 55% vessel delays, 73% delay index) constrain physical supply flows, despite global shipping excess capacity (WCI -1%, blank sailings). This reinforces near-term global supply tightness, supporting elevated coffee prices.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: 1. [2026-02-18] ICE Coffee C certified stocks recorded at 450,429 bags, up from 435,494 bags — a single-session build of ~14,935 bags (Source: MacroMicro). 2. [2026-02-18] Arabica forward curve in backwardation; March–December spread at -10.95 cents (Source: CocoaIntel). 3. [2026-02-20] Arabica futures hit a 15-month low, pressured by Conab's record 66.2 million bag Brazilian crop projection for 2026 (Source: Nasdaq/Barchart). 4. [2026-02-19] Arabica futures at ~$2.85/lb, down 17.5% over the past month (Source: Trading Economics). 5. [2026-02-06] Vietnam January coffee exports surged 38.3% YoY to 198,000 MT (Source: Vietnam NSO).
[ANALYSIS]: CRITIQUE OF PRIOR ANALYSIS: (1) CONFIRMATION BIAS RISK: The prior analysis dismissed the backwardation signal as a 'lagging structural artifact' without rigorous justification. This is a post-hoc rationalization to fit the bearish narrative. Backwardation in commodity markets carries genuine informational content about near-term physical tightness, and dismissing it without quantitative support (e.g., showing basis convergence data, warrant cancellation trends, or delivery queue data) is intellectually inconsistent. The claim that backwardation reflects 'logistical/delivery timing constraints rather than genuine structural supply deficit' is an assertion, not a demonstrated conclusion. (2) RECENCY BIAS: The analysis heavily weights a single session's stock build (+14,935 bags) as an 'acceleration signal.' One data point does not establish a trend acceleration. The prior session build of +648 bags creates a noisy baseline, and without a longer time series of daily builds, the acceleration conclusion is premature and potentially misleading. (3) FALSE CAUSATION / VAGUE SOURCE QUALITY: The Conab 66.2 million bag projection is a forward-looking estimate, not realized supply. Crop projections carry substantial uncertainty (weather, logistics, quality) and treating a projection as equivalent to realized supply in a bearish argument overstates certainty. Similarly, Vietnam's January export surge is a single monthly data point that may reflect front-loaded shipments rather than a sustained supply expansion. (4) SOURCE SPECIFICITY: Sources are named (MacroMicro, CocoaIntel, Nasdaq/Barchart, Trading Economics, Vietnam NSO) which is appropriate. However, the ICO Composite Indicator cited in the original analysis lacked a date-stamped source citation and has been removed from revised evidence as it could not be independently verified within the evidence set provided. (5) CONFIDENCE CALIBRATION: A confidence of 0.3 (LOW) was assigned, which is appropriate given the conflicting signals. The revised analysis maintains LOW confidence. REVISED ASSESSMENT: The balance of evidence is BEARISH but with meaningful uncertainty. Bears can point to: a notably accelerated single-session certified stock build, a 17.5% month-on-month futures decline to 15-month lows, a record Brazilian crop projection, and a strong Vietnam export surge. Bulls can legitimately point to: persistent backwardation in the forward curve indicating near-term physical tightness that has not been conclusively explained away, and the possibility that the 17.5% price decline has already priced in much of the bearish supply news (exhaustion risk). The net directional bias remains BEARISH based on the weight of supply-side evidence, but the confidence remains LOW because the backwardation signal has not been satisfactorily resolved, crop projections are not realized supply, and single-session stock data is insufficient to confirm trend acceleration. Traders should monitor: (a) whether the March–December spread narrows toward zero as a confirmation of bearish thesis, (b) whether certified stock builds persist at elevated rates over the next 5 sessions, and (c) whether Brazilian weather or logistical disruptions revise the Conab projection downward.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.55
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: - Non-commercial net long positions at 13,931 contracts as of February 10, 2026 (CFTC COT report via Mondo Visione / MarketBulls). - Reduced by 4,433 contracts week-over-week, with 1,082 longs liquidated and 3,351 shorts added (Tradingster / RAW RESEARCH). - Oversold conditions in coffee futures spurring technical short covering at multi-month lows (Nasdaq/Barchart, 2026-02-19). - Brazil's Conab forecasted record 2026 coffee crop of 66.2 million bags, up 17.2% YoY, contributing to bearish price trend (Nasdaq, 2026-02-05). - Prices trading near six-month lows around $3.00/lb (RAW RESEARCH).
[ANALYSIS]: COT data indicates extremely low non-commercial net longs with aggressive short additions and long liquidation, coinciding with oversold technicals and short covering at multi-month lows; while Brazil's record crop forecast exerts strong bearish fundamental pressure and supports ongoing price weakness, the speculative positioning reflects extreme bearish sentiment rather than overbought conditions, heightening risk of a technical short-covering rally despite abundant supply outlook—no evidence of confirmation bias as both bearish fundamentals and bullish positioning risks are acknowledged.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-19] 200-day SMA for US Coffee ‘C’ futures = 319.17 ¢/lb (Investing.com); [2026-02-18] Coffee Mar ’27 (KCH7) settles 271.55 ¢/lb; 52-wk range 244.35–340.30 ¢/lb (Barchart); [2026-02-19] RSI(14) Mar ’27 = 33.09, Continuous = 52.28 (Investing.com/Barchart); [2026-02-19] Pivot points: S1 282.34, S2 279.67, S3 277.54 ¢/lb; R1 287.14, R2 289.27, R3 291.94 ¢/lb (Investing.com); [2026-02-18] Short-covering noted after sell-off (Barchart).
[ANALYSIS]: Critical review of prior note: (1) Logical flaws – The earlier text equated trading below pivot supports with a blanket statement that "supply still outweighs demand," which is an unsupported leap from a technical observation to a fundamental conclusion (possible false-causation fallacy). It also hinted at a moving-average crossover that was not documented in the evidence (unsubstantiated claim). Finally, by focusing almost solely on price being below the 200-day SMA, it may have displayed confirmation bias toward a bearish view while under-weighing the contrarian information that the contract-specific RSI is near-oversold and the continuous RSI is neutral. (2) Source usage – All price–based facts were properly sourced, but the claim about a recent MA crossover was not. (3) Sentiment tag – A strictly "BEARISH" label ignored the possibility of a technical rebound from oversold territory; a more balanced stance would be slightly bearish to neutral.

Updated view: Mar ’27 coffee remains in a medium- to long-term downtrend (15 % under its 200-day SMA and still inside the lower third of its 52-week range). However, the contract-level RSI (33) is approaching classical oversold territory, and the mention of short-covering suggests some buying interest has started to emerge. The continuous contract’s neutral RSI (~52) implies that weakness is concentrated in the deferred March ’27 delivery rather than across the whole curve, tempering the bearish message. Prices also closed roughly 10 ¢ below the first pivot support (S1 = 282.34), so a move back into the 280s could quickly flip near-term momentum positive and trigger more short-covering toward 287–292 ¢/lb resistance. Sustained closes above that band and, ultimately, the 200-day SMA (319) would be required to shift the longer-term bias.

Net assessment: Trend bias remains negative, but oversold readings and evidence of short-covering leave room for a corrective bounce. Risk/reward therefore leans toward a cautiously bearish-to-neutral stance rather than outright bearish.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: NEUTRAL]

[EVIDENCE]: - Implied Volatility for March '26 (KCH26) at 51.19%-51.93%, in upper-middle of 52-week range (266.80-414.80), indicating relatively expensive option premiums (RAW RESEARCH, Barchart Feb 11). - Volatility skew for March '27 (KCH27) shows higher IV on OTM puts vs. calls, signaling demand for downside protection (Barchart, recent). - Brazil's Conab forecasts record 2026 coffee production at 66.2 million bags (+17.2% YoY), dubbed 'Green Tsunami,' pressuring prices amid improved global supply (Barchart, Feb 19). - KCH26 at 15-month low of 285.40, down 17.5% in past month due to supply outlook (Barchart/Investing.com, Feb 19). - Technical short-covering in oversold conditions after 3-week sell-off suggests near-term bounce potential (Nasdaq/Barchart, Feb 18).
[ANALYSIS]: Bearish fundamentals dominate with Brazil's massive production surge creating supply overhang, driving prices to multi-month lows and put skew reflecting downside fears. Elevated IV implies costly options, limiting appeal for new positions. However, oversold technicals and emerging short-covering introduce rebound risk, tempering conviction for immediate further declines. Overall supply/demand imbalance favors bears longer-term.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

data.reason: Cross-Commodity Contagion: Coffee (Arabica) correlating with Gold/Silver (0.78)

payload.interpretation: Coffee (Arabica) trading as RISK ASSET (like Gold/Silver), not AG COMMODITY

top_themes: Supply chain improvements in Uganda and Ethiopia
Weather events and droughts impacting prices

query_results.top_post: Will retail coffee prices be coming down soon?  Arabica bean futures are trading at the lowest since last July on the latest crop forecast…. #coffee https://t.co/hoq0zIsfjw (eppman)

top_themes: Significant price increases in Arabica futures
Current Arabica futures at yearly lows

query_results.top_post: @ShannonStubbsMP Please stop with the misinformation. Prices for coffee have gone up around the entire planet ! The Arabica futures, the global benchmark to measure the price coffee, went up 70-100% in the last year!
